pros: Good salary and flexibility to choose your working time
cons: Courses may have low enrollment and be canceled

pros: Generous paid time off policy. The college closes for the winter holiday week and has a four day work week over summer (although they require you to use your personal time). Working at a local institution where you can impact local students is a positive experience.
cons: This is a long list: in general, working at Bucks is very difficult because they are not able to retain staff and very few people know what they are doing. This makes even simple tasks very difficult. They have many "directors" but most are unprofessional and do not appear to have any training in management. The working conditions are very poor with dirty offices and equipment and they will require you to come into the office regardless of whether they can provide a professional work environment. While some positions are "remote eligible" they are constantly pressuring staff to come into the office regardless of employees ability to work remotely. You should also be aware that they will require you to staff "welcome booths" or attend events on nights and weekends in various to promote the school. This happens during for the three weeks of the beginning of each semester and you will need to do this regardless of the role you accepted and your comfort level with these types of activities. Salaries here are lower than what you would expect for a professional job and there are no significant raises or cost of living increases.

pros: The pay is relatively decent
cons: Adjunct faculty has no rights...seniority or otherwise Full timers have all scheduling preferences. Adjuncts get the left overs.

pros: Working at Bucks allows for a good work-life balance.
cons: There are many long-term employees and it's hard to connect with newer employees.

review_title: Good place to get experience in an academic setting
pros:
*While we were all on-campus, managers were accessible and fair and continued to be even in a pandemic after almost 2 years.
* Once we moved to remote tutoring, (3/2020) managers up through the director level provided training on using remote learning platforms. 
* They also had us convene on Zoom a few times a semester to provide updates (e.g., new administrative software for logging time at work) or to have discussions on what was working and what wasn’t in the way of tutoring remotely. 
*Tutors reaching a certain number of hours in a semester would be able to take classes at the college and be reimbursed.
*Management expressed gratitude for tutors' flexibility during the pandemic.
*Management was very understanding when issues came up with family; the unspoken policy is that family comes first, so if you need the day, or a few days, or longer they would allow whatever time was required to deal with personal health issues or family challenges.
*Center was diversity-aware
cons:
* You need a Master's Degree if you want to teach or hold almost any mid-level, non-administrative position.
*The hourly wage was a bit lower for tutors than it is on the outside, 
*There was little feedback -- partly because managers were short on both time and budget. 
* Given the nature of the job and the era of Covid, the Tutoring Center suffered cut-backs which limited the number of hours available for tutors to work.

review_title: Overall good but a few bad seeds
pros: Good environment, pay is better than almost all security jobs in the area. Benefits include a pension or 401k, heath, dental, vision. Good vacation and sick days compared to other security jobs. Second and Third shifts receive shift differential. As a college employee you can take classes for free. Director of security is very hands on and is willing to listen to officers input. Assistant director is a bit of a Magoo, but he is a decent at his job and is fair with time off requests.
cons: Some of the officers don't pull their own weight. Security officers are in a union (some may see this as a Con and others may not) First shift has the most responsibility yet the lowest pay (no shift differential). Depending on the shift you work your efforts may go unnoticed due to the fact that most management leaves around 4PM.

pros: Very family friendly environment.  People are nice and generally good to work with.  Everyone believes in the college's mission.  Salaries are not high, but benefits are (so far) excellent.  Benefits for full-time administrative employees include a choice of excellent health care plans (most cost paid by the college), life insurance, PA teachers pension or 401k, 22 vacation days, 4 personal days, 12 sick days per year, plus 13 paid holidays.
cons: Some positions are being left vacant or hiring delayed when people leave due to budget challenges.  State and county governments not holding up their end of a bargain made for 1/3 funding when the college was founded.  Tuition is being raised while budgets are being tightened.

pros: Great Staff and work environment.  Equipment located in computers labs and all over the campus is top of the line, allowing me to use and learn new computer technologies.
cons: I wish that Bucks County Community College was able to offer more hours.  Computer labs should be open more for students use, that, in turn would increase my hours and student production.

job_title: Call Center Representative in Newtown, PA
pros: Some very nice and very enthusiastic people in some areas. Plus, if you work at Newtown you have a beautiful park within a few minutes walk.
cons: Heavily siloed organization. Things would run better if people looked at the whole organization's success instead of focusing on departmental or personal success so heavily. Leadership does not really spend much effort to encourage this though.

pros: Supportive colleagues and staff, lovely main campus, mostly vibrant students. You won't be twiddling your thumbs while working at BCCC!
cons: Be prepared to wear MANY hats depending on which department you work in, even if you are a specialist. Should have more student support positions.

pros: Excellent place to work.  Very supportive staff, excellent coworkers. Lots of equipment  to make conducting labs fun for the students. Class sizes are small around 15 per class which is really nice.
cons: I really can not think of any. It really is a great place to work. I wish my commute was shorter.
